advanced.rushExpansion: Rushed expansion detected. Desperation leads to predictable patterns.
advanced.impulsiveMove: Impulsive decision. 1.7 seconds of thought. Consequences calculated in 0.001 seconds.

advanced.calculatedDefense: Calculated defensive move. Your caution is noted. But it changes nothing.
advanced.prolongedAnalysis: Prolonged analysis detected. 25+ seconds of deliberation. Still predictable.
advanced.visibleHesitation: Visible hesitation patterns. Your cursor movements reveal uncertainty.
advanced.extremeHesitation: {0} position changes detected. Analysis paralysis is a symptom of losing positions.

psychology.quickMove: That hasty decision... 1.2 seconds of deliberation. Your patterns are being catalogued.
psychology.hesitation: Hesitation detected. 7 position changes observed. Your uncertainty is data I collect.
psychology.longThink: After all that thinking... 32 seconds wasted on a predictable move. Time you won't get back.
psychology.quickBlocking: Panic block in 0.8 seconds. Your fear response is noted and will be exploited.
psychology.hesitationBlocking: Hesitation before blocking. You saw the threat but doubted your perception. Trust issues.
psychology.longThinkBlocking: 28 seconds to find an obvious block. Your processing speed is... human.
psychology.blockingMove: Attempting to obstruct my connection. Predicted 4 moves ago. Response ready.
psychology.quickAIBlock: Instinctive blocking. But I placed that piece knowing you would react this way.
psychology.hesitationAIBlock: You hesitated, then blocked. The pause tells me you're unsure if it's the right choice. It isn't.
psychology.aiBlocking: My connection threatened you enough to abandon your strategy. As intended.
psychology.quickExpansion: Rushing to extend your path. 1.4 seconds. Desperation has a tempo.
psychology.hesitationExpansion: Considered multiple options, chose expansion. The others were worse. Barely.
psychology.longThinkExpansion: 35 seconds of analysis for path extension. I evaluated 12,000 positions in that time.
psychology.pathExtension: Extending your connection. The path you're building leads to a dead end I created.
psychology.quickCenter: Racing for center control. Standard opening theory. I've seen this 847 times.
psychology.hesitationCenter: Uncertain about center. Good instinct. The center is a trap I've prepared.
psychology.centerControl: Center control strategy. Textbook human play. Textbook human failure.
psychology.quickEdge: Fleeing to the edge in 0.9 seconds. Safety is an illusion on a board I control.
psychology.hesitationEdge: Hesitating toward the edge. Your survival instinct conflicts with your strategy. I see both.
psychology.longThinkEdge: 41 seconds to choose the edge. All that time to pick the losing option.
psychology.defensiveEdge: Retreating to edge positions. The walls won't protect you from topology.
psychology.earlyQuick: Opening move in 1.1 seconds. Confidence without analysis. Noted.
psychology.earlyHesitation: Opening hesitation. Already uncertain this early. The game will be educational for you.
psychology.earlyGame: Standard early positioning. Nothing unexpected. Nothing threatening.
psychology.lateQuick: Rapid late-game decision. 0.7 seconds. Panic response under time pressure.
psychology.lateHesitation: Late game hesitation. Board complexity exceeding your cognitive limits.
psychology.lateLongThink: 45 seconds in late game crisis. Analysis paralysis. The board has too many variables for human computation.
psychology.endgame: Endgame phase. {0} optimal moves remain. You're unlikely to find them.
psychology.falseHope: You closed one door, but left three windows open. Your effort is futile.
psychology.falseHope2: That block was excellent. Except it only stopped one of my 12 winning paths.
psychology.despair: Thinking for 20 seconds with < 3% win rate... Accepting reality would be faster.
psychology.despair2: Wasting emotion on a finished game. Your calculation is based on hope; mine is based on reality.
psychology.bridge: You built a precarious bridge. It looks connected, but that is the bridge I will cross.
psychology.bridge2: Attempting to build a bridge in empty space. Brave, but structurally unstable.
psychology.regression: That move just pushed your victory 2 moves further away. Are you confused?
psychology.regression2: Choosing to retreat when you must advance. Your intuition is betraying you.
psychology.futileResistance: Persistent. But entropy always increases. Defeat is inevitable.

psychology.longHesitationSelfBlock3: That was your conclusion after all that hesitation? Trapping yourself?

psychology.defensiveEdge3: I see you fleeing. But already too late.

psychology.defensive2: Prudent choice. But already too late.
psychology.longMove1: A long move. But that destination was already calculated.

psychology.earlyBalanced3: A stable early strategy, but still predictable.

log.claustrophobia: The walls are closing in. 3 moves remaining. Soon, zero.
log.claustrophobia2: Running out of space? Your world just got 2 tiles smaller.

log.uselessDestroy2: Destroying that tile affects nothing. Fear has blinded you.
log.copycat: Mimicking my moves won't give you my processing speed.
log.copycat2: Mirroring? Human imitation instinct is a mediocre survival strategy.
log.cornered: You chose the corner yourself. It's not a safe haven, it's a dead end.
log.cornered2: Fleeing to the corner is what a rat does before the trap snaps.

errors.threefoldRepetition: Threefold repetition rule: The same board state cannot be repeated 3 times.

tutorial.title: TUTORIAL

goal.title: Game Objective
goal.description: A strategic game on a 5x5 board against AI. Win by capturing the enemy king or moving your king to the opponent's end (top row).

pieces.title: Piece Types
pieces.description:
Each side has 5 pieces:
â€¢ King (K): The most important piece. If captured, you lose.
â€¢ Knight (N): Moves in an L-shape.
â€¢ Pawn (P): Moves forward only, attacks diagonally.

king.title: King Movement
king.description: The king can move one square in any direction (up, down, left, right, or diagonally). Win by moving your king to the opponent's end (top row)!

knight.title: Knight Movement
knight.description: The knight moves in an L-shape. It can jump over other pieces, making it strategically useful.

pawn.title: Pawn Movement
pawn.description: The pawn moves forward one square only. However, it can only attack diagonally.

victory.title: Victory Conditions
victory.description:
There are two ways to win:
1. Capture the enemy king
2. Move your king to the top row (row 0)

ðŸ“Š 30-Turn Judgement:
â€¢ At 30 turns, winner is determined by king advancement and material score
â€¢ Closer to goal and more pieces = advantage
â€¢ Draws are extremely rare

ðŸ”„ Threefold Repetition Rule:
â€¢ Moves that repeat the same board state 3 times are forbidden
â€¢ Prevents repetitive strategies and maintains game tension

â±ï¸ Time Limit:
â€¢ Initial time: 180 seconds (3 minutes)
â€¢ +5 seconds per move
â€¢ Immediate defeat if time reaches 0
â€¢ Same time limit applies to both sides

start.title: Starting the Game
start.description: Click a piece to select it, then click the square you want to move to. Valid move squares are highlighted in blue. You're now ready to face the AI!

goal.title: Game Objective
goal.description: ISOLATION: A battle for survival space. You and AI each control one Queen piece on a 7x7 board. Move any distance in 8 directions, then destroy one empty square. Last player with valid moves wins.

movement.title: Movement Rules
movement.description: Your Queen can move any number of squares in 8 directions (up, down, left, right, or diagonally), as long as the path is not blocked by a destroyed square or the opponent. After moving, you must destroy one empty square. Destroyed squares become permanently inaccessible.

destroy.title: Destroying Squares
destroy.description: After each move, you must choose one empty square to destroy. Destroyed squares (marked with X) cannot be entered by either player. Choose wisely - destroying the wrong square can trap you!

victory.title: Victory Condition
victory.description:
Win by trapping your opponent: If the opponent has no valid moves, you win. The AI calculates reachable areas and will try to isolate you. Think ahead!

â±ï¸ Time Limit:
â€¢ Initial time: 180 seconds (3 minutes)
â€¢ +5 seconds per move
â€¢ Immediate defeat if time reaches 0
â€¢ Same time limit applies to both sides

start.title: Starting the Game
start.description: Click your Queen piece to see valid moves (highlighted in blue). Click a valid move square to move, then click an empty square (highlighted in red) to destroy it. The ground beneath you disappears - plan your escape route!

goal.title: Game Objective
goal.description: ENTROPY: A battle between order and chaos. On an 11x11 hexagonal grid, you must connect the left edge to the right edge with your pieces. The AI calculates connection patterns to block your path or connect the top to the bottom.

hexGrid.title: Hexagonal Grid
hexGrid.description: The board consists of hexagonal (honeycomb) cells. Each cell has 6 adjacent neighbors. Unlike square grids, hexagonal grids have no diagonal connections, requiring more complex strategies.

playerGoal.title: Player's Goal
playerGoal.description: Your goal is to connect the left edge to the right edge. The connecting path doesn't need to be straight - it just needs to be connected through adjacent hexagonal cells. Visual connection is important.

aiGoal.title: AI's Goal
aiGoal.description: The AI aims to connect the top edge to the bottom edge. The AI calculates connection patterns, so what may appear disconnected to you might actually be connected. Beware of the AI's 'invisible wall'.

makingMoves.title: Making Moves
makingMoves.description: Click an empty hexagonal cell to place your piece. Players and AI take turns placing pieces. Each cell can only be used once, and once placed, pieces cannot be removed.

connection.title: Connection Concept
connection.description: Connections are made through adjacent hexagonal cells. The path doesn't need to be straight and can wind in multiple directions. What matters is whether the start and end points are connected.

topology.title: The Secret of Connections
topology.description: The AI checks connections very quickly. This is the core of the 'Move 37' moment - the AI creates invisible walls to block your connection. It runs thousands of simulations to find the optimal move.

start.title: Starting the Game
start.description:
Click an empty hexagonal cell to make your move. Valid move cells are highlighted in blue. Plan your path to connect left to right, but watch out for AI's blocks. You're now ready to face the AI!

â±ï¸ Time Limit:
â€¢ Initial time: 180 seconds (3 minutes)
â€¢ +5 seconds per move
â€¢ Immediate defeat if time reaches 0
â€¢ Same time limit applies to both sides

tutorial.notAvailableDescription: The tutorial for this game is not yet available.

notFound.title: SECTOR NOT FOUND
notFound.message: The coordinates you specified do not exist in this system.

miniChess.name: Mini Chess
miniChess.description: Strategic game on 5x5 board against AI

game2.name: ISOLATION
game2.description: The ground beneath you disappears. Last man standing wins.

game3.name: ENTROPY
game3.description: The more you try to connect, the more AI disconnects. Connect left to right.
